messageBody:
I'm not sure what you mean by "popping open the cans". From what
you've described, I think I'd be tempted to write some kind of
paramaterized test case that takes in several potential cases, like:

public static Test suite {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(...);
suite.addTest(
new MailerTest("<Kevin Klinemeier> zipwow@...",
new
InternetAddress("zipwow@...","Kevin Klinemeier","UTF-8"));
suite.addTest(
new MailerTest("zipwow@...",
new InternetAddress("zipwow@...","","UTF-8"));
return suite;
}

public MailerTest(String testAddress, InternetAddress expectedResult) {...}

public void runTest() {
MailSender mailSender = new MailSender();
InternetAddress result = mailSender.setAddress(testAddress);
assertEquals("Wrong result for ["+testAddress+"]",expectedResult,result);
}

Your method takes a collection and not individual addresses, but you
get the idea. Ultimately pretty simple code, if you're familiar with
the paramaterized test case approach.


On Thu, 27 Jan 2005 11:12:51 -0500, Soaring Eagle
<comfortable.numb@...> wrote:
>
> The lines of code:
> > Collection generatedRecipients = broker.getRecipients();
> > assertEquals("Wrong recipients",expectedValues,generatedRecipients);
> indicate that you could compare two Collections in junit. I do not see
> that signature in the junit version that i am using... I can see
> assertEquals(Object, Object), but that may not help...
>
> One piece of info I forgot to mention. The class that has the setter
> method taking a Collection of string email addresses does have a
> getter method returning an array of InternetAddresses... looks like i
> may have to pop open all the cans and actually see whats inside
> each... i was hoping to find something much easier... :-)
>
>
> On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 16:18:30 -0800, Kevin Klinemeier <zipwow@...> wrote:
> > Simple, snide answer: Test your expectations of the results.
> >
> > You mention that the method in question makes some validations. After
> > calling the setter, make your assertions about the exceptions, error
> > codes, or whatever it is you're returning if the validation fails.
> > You may have known that part already.
> >
> > So how do you test the objects created when validation passes? You've
> > got black-box and white-box approaches. I prefer black-box as a first
> > try, but that's mostly because I write the tests first, so the code is
> > really more of an empty box :P
> >
> > To do this black-box-style, look to the other access points to your
> > class. You mention that the private collection is full of
> > InternetAddress objects. Does your class communicate these to a mail
> > broker object? Can you pass in a mock implementation of that object
> > that records what it's been told? Here's a pseudocode example:
> >
> > MockCommunicationsBroker broker = new MockCommunicationsBroker();
> > MailSender mailSender = new MailSender(broker); //class under test --
> > given the mock broker
> >
> > Collection goodValues = getGoodValues();//however you get your test data
> > mailSender.setRecipients(goodValues);
> > mailSender.send(); //presumably interacts with the broker
> >
> > Collection generatedRecipients = broker.getRecipients();
> > assertEquals("Wrong recipients",expectedValues,generatedRecipients);
> > //hand converted expected values that match the input to the setter
> >
> > A white-box approach would be to make your private collection
> > protected or use reflection and a lax security profile to "reach
> > inside" and access them directly. Not as useful for refactoring, and
> > a little less "pure", but easier to implement.
> >
> > -Kevin
> >
> >
> > On Wed, 26 Jan 2005 14:39:00 -0500, Soaring Eagle
> > <comfortable.numb@...> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hello,
> > >
> > > Please bear with me if this is an old oft answered question.

> > > filled with Strings, performs some validations and sets a private
> > > member that is also a collection - filled with
> > > javax.mail.InternetAddress. How do I test this setter method through
> > > JUnit?
